critique: This document primarily delegates authority related to foreign assistance and international development programs. It doesn't directly address domestic policy or social issues, so assessing its position on the traditional left-right spectrum is difficult. The document appears to centralize authority within the executive branch, specifically delegating functions to the Secretary of State, Secretary of Defense, and the Administrator of the Agency for International Development. There is no clear indication of the document's stance on immigration, security vs. liberty, economic regulation, or social inclusion. Therefore, most of the axes will be scored as neutral.
